textField: Artificial neural networks are made up of artificial units that resemble animal neurons, whose *activation* (that is, how *excited* or inhibited they are) depends on the *stimuli* they receive from other neurons and the strength or *weight* and the *sign* of the connections carrying these signals. If the connection between neuron A and B is positive and A is excited, it will tend to *excite* B; if A is inhibited, it will tend to *inhibit* B. When the the connection between A and B is negative and A is excited, it will tend to *inhibit* B; if A is inhibited, it will tend to *excite* B. When a neuron receives stimuli from more than one neuron, the activation of each neuron and the *weight* of the corresponding connection are *multiplied together* and then all are *added up*. The activation of the neuron reacting to the stimulus is computed using an *activation function*. This makes it possible to keep the *activation* of the neuron in a defined *range*.
